(b) the restoration of the incentive and opportunity for the creation of economic growth and national wealth;
(c) the reduction in the burden of personal taxation;
(d) the relief for families by the introduction of income splitting for tax purposes and also of tax rebates for child care;
(e) the review of the distribution of the tax revenue base between the various levels of government; and
(f) the emphasis upon neutral, efficient, and equitable taxes.'.
Yours sincerely, PETER RAE Senator for Tasmania
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The urgent need for fundamental reform of the Australian system of the raising and expenditure of revenue which involves the need for- (a) the total review of expenditure;
(b) the restoration of the incentive and opportunity for the creation of economic growth and national wealth;
(c) the reduction in the burden of personal taxation;
(d) the relief for families by the introduction of income splitting for tax purposes and also of tax rebates for child care;
(e) the review of the distribution of the tax revenue base between the various levels of government; and
(f) the emphasis upon neutral, efficient, and equitable taxes.

This is a matter or urgency and the Opposition will speak to it as a team. The first point that I emphasise is that the Opposition will speak as a team on this matter because, as I shall elaborate a little later, unfortunately the public debate on this most important issue has been confused by the disparate nature of the desperate measures taken by the present Government in encouraging public debate of the issues involved. There is no doubt that the tax system is in need of fundamental reform. That is a widely held view. It is held by the public, as demonstrated in the Bulletin of 19 March. In that issue, the results of a Morgan poll were published which showed that 58 per cent of Australians believed that as far as they were concerned the general level of tax was unreasonable; that is, nearly three-fifths of Australians believe that the general level of tax is unreasonable. When one has regard to how many taxpayers there are, one sees that almost all taxpayers believe that the level is unreasonable. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, in the policy speech on 13 November 1984 said:
. . . a thoroughgoing review and reform of the entire tax system . . . will be central to all our tasks in our second term.

He then set out nine principles which would apply to that review of taxation. Those nine principles are well known. I will not pause to read them in detail, but they have caused considerable concern. I will deal with them later as they constitute some restraint on the approach which can be adopted to the overall review. In an article in the AFR Review of December 1984, Christopher Jay made some comments which I would adopt. He said:

The problem is that large proportions of the community's savings, the funds which should be bankrolling productive enterprise and economic growth, are being diverted into avenues of marginal economic utility.

The culprit is Australia's tax system, more specifically the high rates of marginal tax which virtually ensure that for a large proportion of investors the primary consideration in any rational investment program is how it can be structured to minimise taxation payments.
That misallocation of resources needs to be overcome. Paragraph 5.1 of the taxation policy issued by the coalition in respect of the election last year reads:

The Coalition parties not only believe that the current overall burden of taxation is too high, but also that the taxation system is in need of reform. Labor has preferred to hide behind the convenient excuse of extended consultation, devoid of any policy framework, to avoid having to reveal its plans for new taxes on capital and assets before its unnecessary early election.
It is asking for a blank cheque on tax.

That, apparently, is still the situation. What was eventually forthcoming from the Prime Minister during the election campaign was a statement of what he chose to call a trilogy. The trilogy can be summarised in these words: First, the Government would not increase Commonwealth taxation as a proportion of gross domestic product; second, it would reduce government outlays as a proportion gross domestic product; third, it would not increase the deficit as a proportion gross domestic product. I was impressed by what Mr Maximilian Walsh, well known for his commentaries on public matters, said when he referred to the Oxford Dictionary meaning of 'trilogy' as 'a set of three tragedies to be performed in immediate succession'. That may be an unfortunate characterisation of what this Government is taking Australia towards. The trilogy, if it is to be implemented, will simply freeze us into the present high tax, high spending situation which has existed in this country since this Government came to power. We are now suffering from paying the highest percentage of tax and having the highest expenditure as a percentage of our national wealth since this country was formed at Federation. That is the situation which this Government has brought this country to.

I find it more than passing curious that the trilogy commitments were given, because they were given when the economy was suffering very severely from the impact of external and internal events. So far as external events are concerned, the export markets available for both our rural products and our mining products are squeezed both as to quantity and as to price. We are suffering the judgment which was inevitable from the time that the Australian dollar was floated, something with which we do not disagree but something which subjected this country, its management and its economy to the judgment of the international market-place; and the international market-place has this year passed that judgment. It has devalued the Australian dollar, as Senator Chaney said when speaking earlier, by 13c in the three weeks leading up to the Governor-General's speech. It has devalued the Australian dollar as a judgment of the management and re-election of the present Government. It is a judgment of no confidence in the present Government of this country. I believe that again will make the achievement of the trilogy that much harder.

When one has regard further to the increased demands being made from various sectors of the community, including the Australian Council of Trade Unions, regarded by some as the real government of the country, one finds the prospects of the achievement of the trilogy are so small as to be likely to induce people with anything in the nature of a suspicious mind to believe that perhaps the confusion being created in relation to the taxation debate at the moment is an obfuscation to cover up the fact that net taxes will be increased to overcome the problems of the present Government but under a different guise so that the Government cannot be accused of a direct breach of the trilogy. I believe we must approach tax reform from a different point of view. We must not approach it from the point of view of setting down certain basic and fundamental principles outside which we cannot go, thus winding up with a situation which, whatever we do in the discussion and the consideration within the Parliament, within the parties, in government and within the summit, is subject to the veto of an outside body, the ACTU. That is the situation which as late as this afternoon Senator Walsh reaffirmed in the way in which he answered a question I asked of him. Whatever happens in the debate which takes place, it is subject to the veto of the ACTU which, if it does not get what it wants, can then say that it will not play ball in the way in which Senator Walsh outlined and, therefore, the whole thing cannot go ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not even mention the ACTU.

—I will quote what has been said by others as well so that, if Senator Walsh does not wish to be involved in it, he can just increase the number of differences within his party. Let us first look at the essentials. The first essential we believe it is necessary to look at in this country is a reduction in expenditure, in the rate of growth of public indebtedness. The rate of growth of taxation is a reflection of the rate of growth of public expenditure in this country at a Commonwealth level and at a State level as well as at local government level. Public expenditure in this country has risen dramatically. We must look also to the creation of wealth because, without the creation of wealth, there is a diminishing tax base and all we can then look at is which taxes we are going to impose to try to make up for the fact that we get less from each form of tax because the total wealth available has been diminished. The Australian Labor Party is not going down that track. It is going down the track of the intrusion of an ideological prejudice-an economically ignorant, economically inefficient and economically counter-productive approach, a doctrinal approach, to tax reform which will leave Australia and its taxpayers still disenchanted, without incentive and suffering the feeling of injustice which exists in this country at the moment as a result of the introduction of the assets test as it is felt by the small family farmer.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an apparent manic determination on the part of the Government to seize capital at all costs as if capital, rather than being for the generation of growth and employment opportunity in this country and for the creation of national wealth, were some vile disease to be stamped out at all costs. We see the Hawke-Keating Government again succumbing to its Left extremists as it did over the MX missile matter and the ANZUS matter when we had the back-tracking which took place. So extreme is the factionalism with regard to this matter that the Australian Labor Party Centre Left held its own seminar on taxation at the beginning of March in which its members came up with their own policy. It was interesting that their chief adviser and spokesman is reported to have advised them that a capital gains tax, the darling of the Left as a tax reform measure, would be unrewarding in the return it would provide.

Let me refer very quickly to the Opposition's approach. At the time of the election last year, after 20 months in government, the Government still refused to tell Australians whether it would introduce a capital gains tax, death duties and a wealth tax-and it still refuses, although many of its members are on record as saying that they favour this course; whether it would be broadening the indirect tax base-and again today Senator Button and Senator Walsh refused to commit themselves to a view in relation to that; whether it would be doing something about the average wage earner moving into the 46c tax bracket or the 47c bracket, as it really is; or whether it would do something to relieve the tax burden on the family. In contrast, firm and clear policies have been put forward by the coalition, which proposes the provision of a new deal for families to reduce the tax burden and to assist with the cost of child care, and to relieve the tax burden for one income families in the 46c bracket or those who are moving towards it. This will be partly paid for by a broadening of the indirect tax base, a firm commitment to direction so that people know in which direction we wish to move. We will not be introducing a capital gains tax, death duties or other taxes on capital; and we will not have a bar of Labor's assets test or the 31c tax on lump sum superannuation. Those are the measures which, in government, the coalition would take.

There is in Australia at the moment very high taxation and very high public sector borrowing, leading to the assessment that public sector debt has risen to the stage at which it costs the average taxpayer $34 per week simply to fund the interest bill alone on public debt in this country. There is accruing and accrued, but undisclosed, through a number of matters, another huge debt, part of which relates to the devaluation which has taken place and the overseas loans and the cost of interest and repayment of those loans in Australian dollars, which will now be billions of dollars more than it would otherwise have been. There is also accrued, but not disclosed, a liability in respect of Commonwealth superannuation, particularly by statutory authorities, of mammoth proportions. This is a public debt which is not included in the public debt to which I referred.

I wish to be taken not in any way as talking down the Australian economy but, rather, as being realistic. There is an urgency that we face these matters and face them fairly and squarely. We find in today's Australian Financial Review that the front page headline is: 'US investors scathing about Australia'. The article states:
One of the largest and most influential broking and investment banking groups in the US has delivered a virtually unequivocal thumbs down to the Australian market.

It talks about 'the stifling tax regime' as being one of the important aspects of that problem. We must remove the stifling nature of that tax regime. We must take those measures which will ensure that this country is not viewed in the way in which that group of American bankers viewed it after a visit here.

We need to look at the tax base and, in particular, at the extent to which the tax base has been narrowed by the development of the mixed economy and the extent to which areas of that mixed economy are able to engage, through statutory authorities and other government bodies, in the avoidance, evasion or non-application of tax which would otherwise be applicable to economic activity which is being undertaken. I remind honourable senators that revenue forgone in that way is equivalent to a tax cut and amounts just as much to a subsidy as would a direct subsidy. Australia Post Courier is a good example of that. It carries out an economic activity that can be carried out equally well by other areas of the community but is not carried out because government carries it out without paying sales tax, excise duties and all the other taxes which would normally be paid on that sort of undertaking.

We find that there is a proposal for a capital gains tax, which is generally regarded by small business as absolutely anathema. The Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia has made that abundantly clear. The ineffectiveness of such a tax was made clear in an editorial in the Australian on 18 March this year and by a series of articles by Dr Ian Spry, QC, the editor of the Australian Tax Review, who has equally made clear the disastrous potential effects of that tax, which include one matter which has not been specified yet-I pick it under the limitation of time-the increase in housing rentals, because inevitably a capital gains tax would contract the stock of rental housing available and would increase the rentals demanded by the owners of rental houses. COSBOA has made clear its objection to the constraining influence of the nine principles. I refer to its January 1985 review. Finally, it was reported on 1 November 1984, and reaffirmed by Senator Walsh today-as was my understanding-that the Prime Minister had said that before any increase in indirect taxation 'it will be necessary to get an agreement with and from the trade unions to ensure that that does not add to the inflationary process.' In other words, honourable senators opposite are not in government. Mr Hawke is not in government. The Australian Council of Trade Unions has to give its imprimatur irrespective of what may be agreed to at the tax summit.

In summary, the true nature of what is happening is a vast charade, a ploy to change the system without reducing the revenue. On this matter, the Hawke Government is falling apart. It is desperate for funds and disparate as to how to gain those funds. We need genuine reform, a total review of expenditure and the restoration of the incentive and opportunity for the creation of economic growth and national wealth. We need the reduction in the burden of personal taxation and relief for families by the introduction of income splitting for tax purposes and for tax rebates for child care. We need the review of the distribution of the tax revenue base between the various levels of government and the emphasis upon neutral, efficient and equitable taxes. That is an urgent necessity for this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I used to think that only dilettante Democrats put together packages which were unachievable and internally inconsistent in the full knowledge that they would never be called upon to accept the ultimate political responsibility for implementing them in government. From the package which has just been presented and, indeed, just read, by Senator Peter Rae, I must assume that the Liberal Party has also abandoned all hope of returning to government and, therefore, of accepting any responsibility for the package which it has presented this afternoon. The Government will, of course, be voting against the urgency motion, for reasons which I will go into in detail if time permits.

SPEECH.PARA: I was somewhat astounded to hear Senator Rae citing with approval the Barton Biggs paper circulated by Morgan Stanley and reported on the front page of today's Australian Financial Review. I wondered whether Senator Rae knew that Mr Biggs had argued that we need a capital gains tax in Australia-something which Senator Rae had explicitly rejected during his speech in support of the motion. The Opposition appears to be as confused on taxation questions as it was when it was in government and almost as confused as it was last week when its various luminaries were giving contradictory versions of what the Opposition would in fact do with tax legislation in the Senate, a subject to which I shall return.

Towards the end of Senator Rae's speech, he referred to what he called the veto of the Australian Council of Trade Unions-I think that was the emotive and fairly meaningless phrase-which is his way of dealing with the incontestably sensible statements from various members of the Government that no significant increase in indirect taxation should be contemplated unless there has been an assurance that the consequential consumer price index rises will not be passed on into wages through indexation. Obviously, the Opposition is of the view that a government should blithely proceed to boost the CPI through changes in the tax system, then pay no heed whatsoever as to whether those higher nominal CPI rates would flow into wages. The Opposition has learnt nothing since 1978, when it did precisely that. It increased by about $2.5 billion receipts from the crude oil levy, which boosted the CPI by several percentage points and which flowed on into wages. 'Act first and think later' was the motto of the Opposition in 1978. Regrettably it is the motto still.

Returning to the Biggs-Morgan Stanley document upon which Senator Rae apparently sets great store, it is interesting to note that the document primarily was criticising the legacy of 30 years of incompetent Liberal government. For example, Biggs states:
Australia also suffers from a stifling tax policy, which the Hawke Government hopes to address in a tax summit this summer.
He continues:
There seems to be a developing feeling on the part of labour, management and the politicians that confrontation isn't working--
Finally, he expresses some optimism about the future when he says:
. . . it is such a great country that the time will come to own lots of Australian stocks.

That is only one man's opinion, of course, but I find it interesting that the Liberal Party has chosen to cite Mr Biggs as some sort of guru or oracle, when Mr Biggs stated very clearly that there is a desperate need for a capital gains tax in Australia-something that the Liberal Party explicitly rejects or, at least, one of its factions says that it rejects. The truth is that there is a greater, a more significant and a more self-imposed fiscal constraint on this Government than there has been on any previous government. Assurances have been given that government spending, taxation and the deficit as proportions of gross domestic product will not exceed this year's levels.

The absolute levels of government spending are to some extent influenced by value judgments, by history and by the institutions which exist in a particular country. International comparisons of spending as a proportion of gross domestic product can be quite misleading. Having said that, I stress that it is quite clear to anybody who adopts a dispassionate approach that levels of spending in Australia, as opposed to those in countries with which we normally compare ourselves, are not high. However, it is the view of this Government-a view which I certainly share-that there are some existing programs upon which public funds are spent, on which the continuation of that spending cannot be justified, and which ought to be either eliminated or reduced. The principle which is guiding this Government in pursuit of the stated goal of expenditure reductions is social justice and economic efficiency.

Taxation, in the long term at least-even the Opposition has recognised this-is the mirror image of government spending. Similar comparisons are made about the level of taxation in Australia compared with that in other countries, with similar and often misleading results because insufficient account is taken of variations from one country to another. Those simplistic and misleading international comparisons frequently lead to false assertions. One of those false assertions is that the total level of taxation in Australia, compared with international standards, is high-particularly for income tax. That arises partly because in most European countries there is a separate income tax and a social security levy, whereas in Australia the two are rolled into one and have been for the last 30 years. Therefore, what is identified as personal taxation in one country is not comparable to what is called personal taxation in another country. Likewise, recently published figures quoting the maximum marginal rate of income tax in the United States do not bother to add that that is the maximum Federal marginal rate and that in most, if not all, States of the United States of America a State income tax is applied in addition to the Federal income tax.

In total, when account is taken of all these things, Australian tax is not high by international standards. However, for reasons that I will explain in a minute, it is correct that the maximum marginal rate of tax being paid by a very large number of Australian taxpayers is high by international standards. It is important to note the difference between marginal tax rates and average tax rates. For example, it is true that the person on average weekly earnings today pays a marginal tax rate of 46c in the dollar, but the average tax rate is less than half that. Indeed, it is slightly below 22c in the dollar. Throughout a very wide range of incomes to fully employed people, which can be roughly defined as the band from $10,000 to $35,000, it would encompass almost all incomes earned by people in full time employment. With very little deviation throughout that range, the average rate of tax paid is half the marginal rate paid. There is a good deal of confusion promoted and compounded by members of the Opposition that the marginal rate paid is, in fact, the average rate. In general, and there are some deviations from this, the average rate is only half the marginal rate.

Many people believe that the maximum marginal rate is too high. Again, that depends on the way in which one looks at it. The maximum marginal rate is now lower than, or as low as, it has been at any time for more than 40 years. In the late 1940s and the early 1950s the maximum marginal rate was 75 per cent, and virtually throughout the rest of the 1950s, 1960s and early 1970s it was either 65 per cent or 66 per cent. It is now 60 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but the place at which it cut in was entirely different.

—I am about to come to that and explain why. So the maximum marginal rate is not high in Australia by historical standards. What is different is the rate at which either the maximum or high marginal rates cut in. Whereas 30-odd years ago the maximum marginal rate, which was 75 per cent, did not cut in until around 30 times the average weekly earnings, today it cuts in at less than double the average weekly earnings, although the maximum marginal rate is now 60 per cent, not 75 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of reasons for the fact that high marginal rates cut in at a lower relative level of income than they have traditionally in Australia. Those reasons include the very large increase in the tax-free threshold of income which, after conversion to dollars at 1985 values, was around $1,000 through the 1950s, 1960s and early 1970s and is now nearly $4,600. All taxpayers have a very large amount of tax-free income below the threshold. A significant number of taxpayers have incomes entirely below the threshold and therefore pay no income tax. The second reason is that there has been some narrowing of the taxation base. The third and perhaps the most important reason of all-probably of equal importance to the increase in the tax-free threshold-is that there is widespread tax evasion and avoidance. This practice was encouraged by a sequence of bizarre judgments of the Barwick High Court at the root of which, in almost all cases of tax avoidance, is a contrived arrangement which converts what ought to be income, and taxed as income, into capital.

Principally for that reason, the Australian income tax system, which is nominally progressive, is throughout most of the range probably proportional and at the upper end of the range is probably regressive because of the widespread existence of schemes to minimise taxable income through the conversion of tax receipts from income into capital. The system is mostly proportional-it is regressive at the highest end, and progressive at the lowest end. In total the tax system is probably not progressive. For those reasons the Australian income tax system is seen-I believe correctly seen-as being unjust. It is probably also inefficient. For that reason the Government has decided to hold a taxation summit in July this year at which options for a wide range of potential new, varied or existing taxes will be canvassed. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said yesterday, no firm Government decisions have been made on any of those specific proposals, and nobody in the Government, to my knowledge is absolutely committed to any particular tax or any particular form of tax. However, may I say that it is difficult to see how the widespread avoidance of income tax, which is a major cause-probably the major cause-of the quite high marginal tax rates cutting in at fairly low levels of income, can be closed off without some form of capital gains tax. I can only assume that those people who assert dogmatically, as Senator Peter Rae has just done and as many, although not all, his colleagues have done, that under no circumstance should any form of capital gains tax ever be considered are voting for the continuation of tax avoidance, for the perpetuation of a system which is both unjust and inefficient in terms of its effect on investment decisions and resource allocation. I trust that if those people do have any good-will-I believe that Senator Rae generally does-they will think again about that particular question.

Senator Rae today, and other prominent spokesmen for the Opposition, have repeated the coalition belief that the burden of taxation is in total too high, regardless of its distribution, and have drawn, correctly, the linkage, at least in the long term, between taxation and expenditure. I find it extraordinary that the Opposition should continue to say that when it has just been through an election campaign in which it promised to increase expenditure by $2.4 billion, half of which would have been in the first year, in which it promised a variety of taxation concessions which would have cost the revenue around $2 billion, and simultaneously promised to reduce the deficit. Of course that is cargo cultism. I am surprised that someone of Senator Rae's knowledge, and at most times integrity, could have repeated that today.

Members of the Opposition love to talk about fiscal responsibility. An affection for fiscal responsibility is regrettably something that the present Opposition developed after it left government. The chief exponent of fiscal responsibility is the former Treasurer, Mr Howard. It ought to be noted, in view of this drive to generate the illusion of fiscal responsibility, that Mr Howard's expenditure target was overshot in every Budget he produced. Following every Budget that Mr Howard produced as Treasurer the Government ended up spending much more than he forecast at the time of presentation. Of course his zenith was his final Budget in which he forecast a deficit of $1.5 billion, which produced a final outcome of $4.5 billion and a prospective deficit for the succeeding financial year of $9.6 billion. He overspent his Budget in every year. No manager of a private business operating on that basis could remain solvent for the length of time that Mr Howard was Treasurer of Australia. I guess ultimately Australia became insolvent under Mr Howard and that is one of the reasons Mr Howard is no longer in office. Moreover, if we look also at the qualitative aspects of the Howard Government as well as the quantitative aspects, we find that throughout the Howard period capital expenditure was starved. From a proportion of Budget outlays in 1974-75 totalling 25 per cent, it fell to below 9 per cent by 1981-82. Real growth in expenditure for capital purposes was negative in all but one of the Howard Budgets. So on both quantitative and qualitative grounds the former Treasurer must be regarded as a failure.

As I said in the beginning, the Government will not vote for this Opposition motion. There are inconsistencies within it. It is principally a grab-bag designed to appeal to the greedy. If adopted it would impose quite severe penalties on some groups but would do nothing to restore equity or efficiency to the taxation system. The pursuit of equity and efficiency is the objective of this Government.

—Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented.
